properties.Title: Armed And Dangerous Person
properties.Summary:
Description: Police investigating an armed and dangerous person in the Town of Millhaven, area of Highwy 33 and County Rd 4. Check with the County website for EDR. Please shelter in place of safety until further notice.
Expires: 2020-11-26T23:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Provincial Emergency Operations Centre, 2020-11-26T19:40:42-05:00, 9C5A39BC-59F6-D8C3-18A2-B8128A8A4A50
Area: Area surrounding Highway 33 and Doyle Road in Loyalist Township.
properties.Author: Provincial Emergency Operations Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain is expected. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: This afternoon and tonight. Remarks: Central New Brunswick (north of the Fredericton area): Periods of light freezing rain or rain is expected to develop this afternoon and persist this evening, becoming just rain by midnight. Although amounts are expected to be light, over high terrain, the freezing rain could last several hours. Northern New Brunswick: Periods of light snow or freezing rain are expected to develop this afternoon then change to light freezing rain or rain this evening. Precipitation is expected to change to showers after midnight. In some localities, especially over high terrain, several hours of freezing rain is likely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T07:00:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T15:01:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2475497618.2020
Area: Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An approaching weather system will track through the central interior tonight and Friday. Snow from the system will begin early this evening and continue through Friday morning. The snow is expected to become mixed with rain Friday afternoon as snow levels rise. Total snowfall accumulations up to 25 cm are possible before Friday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T14:47:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T22:48:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0492860704.2020
Area: North Columbia, Kinbasket
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of heavy rain is forecast for the central coast of British Columbia for today and Friday. A pair of frontal waves will make landfall in succession on the Central Coast today and Friday. These two frontal waves will bring heavy rain to the coastal sections of the Central Coast. Rainfall amounts of 120 to 150 mm are expected by Friday evening. The forecast heavy rain on top of antecedent moisture may result in localised flooding or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T04:35:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T12:36:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4051304297.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An approaching weather system will track through the central interior tonight and Friday giving snow to the area. Snow over the McGregor region will continue tonight and snow over the Yellowhead region as well the Highway will start this evening. Total snow accumulations of 15 to 20 cm can be expected by Friday evening. Over the Prince George, Stuart - Nechako regions and the southern sections of Lakes District, Snow from the system will start overnight and become heavier on Friday. The snow will taper off to a few flurries Friday evening with total amounts near 15 cm possible. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T15:45:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T23:46:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0925205787.2020
Area: Yellowhead, Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako, Prince George, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong winds will reduce visibilities to near zero over these areas this afternoon and evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: About 20 cm of snow has fallen in Dawson and over sections of the southern Dempster Highway. A low pressure centre moving across the northern Yukon continues to give heavy snow to Dawson and southern Dempster Highway. A further 5 to 10 cm is expected before the snow ends this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T05:14:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T18:41:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2285515335.2020
Area: Dawson, Dempster

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An extended period of freezing rain is expected. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Central New Brunswick (north of the Fredericton area): Periods of light freezing rain or rain will persist this evening, becoming primarily rain by midnight. Higher terrain is where the freezing rain will likely persist the longest. Northern New Brunswick: Periods of light snow or freezing rain will change to light freezing rain or rain this evening. Precipitation is expected to change to showers after midnight. In some localities, especially over high terrain, several hours of freezing rain is likely. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T06:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T19:59:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0677717832.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An approaching weather system will track through the central interior tonight and Friday. Snow will begin over the McGregor region near noon and then ease before Friday morning. Snow amounts of 5 cm are expected over McGregor today with a further 10 cm falling tonight. The snow will spread over the Yellowhead region by early this evening and continue through Friday. Snowfall amounts of 10 cm is expected by early Friday morning, with a further 5 to 10 cm possible during the day. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T04:35:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T12:36:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3468781979.2020
Area: Yellowhead, McGregor

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog will persist across the region through the evening hours. Some areas may see the dense fog persist through the night. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. An upper warm front is expected to cause heavy snow beginning overnight tonight, and continue until Saturday afternoon. The snowfall warning may need to be expanded north because there is uncertainty as to how far north the warm front will push. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong cold front stalled over northern Vancouver Island today will begin to move southward overnight and cross Vancouver Island on Friday. Winds over northern sections of East Vancouver Island and Sunshine Coast will rise to southeast 50 to 70 km/h overnight as the front approaches. Winds will ease late Friday afternoon as the front passes. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T15:55:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T23:56:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2122247612.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River

Snow from the system will begin this evening near Anahim Lake and ease Friday morning with total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A weather system will stall over the Central Coast tonight and Friday and a long episode of heavy rain, with rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm, is expected. Heavy rain will continue tonight over northern sections near Zeballos and Tahsis. Rainfall amounts near 100 mm can be expected by Friday afternoon. Rain will ease Friday evening as the system moves southwards away from the region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T15:54:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T23:55:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2973390416.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm are expected by Friday evening. A frontal system will stall over the Central Coast tonight and Friday with a long episode of heavy rain. Heavy rain over the inland sections of the Central Coast will continue tonight and Friday. The rain will ease on Friday evening. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T15:50:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T23:51:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2272024865.2020
Area: Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of heavy rain is forecast for the Central Coast and northwestern Vancouver Island tonight through Friday. A pair of frontal waves will make landfall in succession on the Central Coast tonight through Friday. These two frontal waves will bring heavy rain to the coastal sections of the Central Coast and northwestern Vancouver Island. Total rainfall amounts for the event are expected to range from 120 to 150 mm by Friday evening on the Central Coast with about 90 mm near Port Alice. The forecast heavy rain on top of antecedent moisture increases the risk of localised flooding or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T15:51:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T23:52:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1549195341.2020
Area: North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intensifying low pressure system tracking from Arviat to Hudson Strait will lead to strong northeast winds over Coral Harbour beginning this evening. The strong winds, with gusts up to 80 km/h, combined with fresh and falling snow, will lead to blizzard or near blizzard conditions beginning this evening that will persist into Friday before easing through the day. This winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning as the event nears and conditions are monitored. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T12:25:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T20:26:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2728047081.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 cm of snow is expected for Highway 97 and the Pine Pass today. A frontal system moving across central BC this morning will bring snow at times heavy to the Pine Pass. The snow will continue until late this afternoon before tapering off to scattered flurries as the system slumps south. Gusty southwesterly winds may lead to localized areas of drifting snow which could reduce visibilities. Another system will affect the region on Friday with more snow expected. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-27T04:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-26T19:08:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0466323155.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

The freezing rain will end during the evening or overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
